title: Ralph Hasenhuttl sends groveling message to Southampton fans after 9-0 loss to Leicester
text:
Ralph Hasenhuttl was apologetic after his side were destroyed by Leicester (Picture: Getty Images)

Ralph Hasenhuttl has apologised to Southampton fans and taken responsibility for his team’s performance in a record-breaking 9-0 loss to Leicester City.

The Saints were abysmal at St Mary’s on Friday night as they were destroyed by the Foxes, who pulled off the biggest away win in top flight history.

The home team were down to 10 men after just 12 minutes when Ryan Bertrand was shown a red card after VAR checked a bad challenge on Ayoze Perez.

However, Hasenhuttl refused to blame the result on the numbers deficit, taking the responsibility on his own shoulders.

‘It would be easy to say it was because of the red card after 10 minutes, I think it’s not the right moment to discuss every goal and everything in the result,’ the Austrian told Sky Sports.

‘I take 100% responsibility for the result today, it was a no performance from my team and this cannot happen in this way.

Jamie Vardy, Youri Tielemans and Ayoze Perez all scored at St Mary’s Stadium (Picture: Getty Images)

‘The best thing I saw today, beside the opponent, was the crowd that stayed in the stadium, our crowd, the guys that stayed and how they acted is more than we deserved today.

‘We apologise for this no performance today.

‘I’ve never had such an experience in my entire managing career. I never thought that such a thing would happen, but it can, as you have seen today.’

Southampton found themselves 5-0 down at half-time and did little to stem the flow of goals after the break.

The remarkable game saw hat-tricks from Jamie Vardy and Ayoze Perez, with Ben Chilwell, Youri Tielemans and James Maddison all scoring as well.

Hasenhuttl admitted it will be difficult for his team to recover from the shocking defeat, admitting that his players lacked commitment.

‘We made two changes and tried to have a second half without conceding a goal, but the two substitutes didn’t make us more stabilised,’ continued the Saints boss.

‘How we worked against the ball was not committed enough and the opponent showed in every attacking situation how strong they are and we couldn’t defend it.

‘We must look on the players and how we stand up again. [It is] Not easy [to recover] but we have to stand up again and show a different face.’

The Austrian remained calm for much of the post-match interview, but began to lose patience when he was asked if he was in a state of shock.

‘When I stand there for 90 minutes and see one goal after the other and there was no chance to defend and every goal we conceded you must think that there is no team on the pitch, it is not really nice standing out there, if you ask me if I’m shocked, what do you think?’ Hasenhuttl raged.
